Considera un diálogo básico D, que consiste en una secuencia de movimientos mi, con un grafo de argumentos correspondiente AG. 1. Cada movimiento mi+1 que es relevante para R1 es relevante para R2. La afirmación contraria no es válida. 2. Cada movimiento mi+1 que es relevante en R3 es relevante en R2. La afirmación contraria no es válida. 3. No todos los movimientos mi+1 que son relevantes para R1 son relevantes para R3, y no todos los movimientos mi+1 que son relevantes para R3 son relevantes para R1. Demostración. Para 1, considera cómo el movimiento mi+1 puede satisfacer R1. La Proposición 3.1 nos dice que si Ai+1 puede cambiar el estado del argumento denotado por la raíz v1 (que, como se observó anteriormente, es el primer nodo) de AG, entonces vi+1 debe estar conectado a la raíz. Esto es precisamente lo que se requiere para satisfacer R2, y se demuestra que la relación se mantiene. Para ver que la afirmación contraria no se cumple, tenemos que considerar lo que se necesita para cambiar el estado de r (ya que la Proposición 3.1 nos dice que la conexión no es suficiente para garantizar un cambio de estado; si lo fuera, la relevancia de R1 y R2 coincidiría). Para que mi+1 cambie el estado de la raíz, tendrá que (1) hacer que el argumento A representado por r sea inaceptable, si era aceptable antes del movimiento, o (2) aceptable si era inaceptable antes del movimiento. Dada la definición de aceptabilidad, esta se puede lograr (1) ya sea directamente socavando el argumento representado por r, en cuyo caso vi+1 estará directamente conectado a r por algún borde, o socavando algún argumento A que forma parte del conjunto de argumentos no socavados que defienden A. En el último caso, vi+1 estará directamente conectado al nodo que representa A y, por la Proposición 4.1, a r. Para lograr (2), vi+1 tendrá que socavar un argumento A que actualmente está socavando a A, o está socavando un argumento que de otro modo defendería a A. Ahora, considera además que mi+1 presenta un argumento Ai+1 que socava el argumento representado por algún nodo v, pero este último argumento se defiende contra Ai+1. En tal caso, el conjunto de argumentos aceptables no cambiará, por lo que el estado de Ar no cambiará. Por lo tanto, un movimiento que sea relevante para R2 no necesita ser relevante para R1. Para 2, considera que mi+1 puede satisfacer R3 simplemente agregando un nodo que esté conectado a vi, el último nodo que se agregará a AG. Por la Proposición 4.1, está conectado a r y por lo tanto es relevante para R2. Para ver que la afirmación contraria no es válida, considera que un movimiento relevante en R2 puede conectarse a cualquier nodo en AG. La primera parte del 3 sigue un argumento similar al que acabamos de usar: un movimiento relevante para R1 no tiene que conectarse a vi, solo a algún v que sea parte del grafo. La segunda parte sigue porque un movimiento relevante para R3 puede introducir un argumento Ai+1 que socava el argumento Ai presentado por el movimiento anterior (y por lo tanto vi+1 está conectado a vi), pero descubre que Ai se defiende contra Ai+1, evitando un cambio de estado en la raíz. Lo más interesante no son tanto los resultados, sino por qué se mantienen, ya que esto revela algunos aspectos de la interacción entre la relevancia y la estructura de los gráficos de argumentos. Por ejemplo, para reformular un caso de la demostración de la Proposición 4.2, un movimiento que es relevante según la R3 por definición tiene que añadir un nodo al grafo de argumentos que esté conectado al último nodo que se añadió. Dado que un movimiento que es relevante para R2 puede agregar un nodo que se conecta en cualquier lugar en un grafo de argumentos, cualquier movimiento relevante para R3 será relevante para R2, pero la afirmación contraria no es cierta. Resulta que podemos aprovechar la interacción entre la estructura y la relevancia que las Proposiciones 4.1 y 4.2 han comenzado a iluminar para establecer relaciones entre los protocolos que rigen los diálogos y los grafos de argumentos construidos durante dichos diálogos. Para hacer esto, necesitamos definir protocolos de tal manera que se refieran a la estructura del grafo. Tenemos: Definición 4.3. Un protocolo es de un solo camino si todos los diálogos que se ajustan a él construyen grafos de argumentos que tienen solo una rama. Proposición 4.3. Un protocolo básico P es de un solo camino si, para todo i, el conjunto de movimientos permitidos Mi en el movimiento i son todos relevantes en R3. La afirmación contraria no es válida. Prueba. La relevancia R3 requiere que cada nodo añadido al grafo de argumentos esté conectado al nodo anterior. Comenzando desde el primer nodo, esto construye de forma recursiva un árbol con solo una rama, y la relación se mantiene. El recíproco no se cumple porque incluso si uno o más movimientos en el protocolo son relevantes para R1 o R2, puede ser el caso de que, debido a la elección retórica de un agente o a su conocimiento, cada argumento seleccionado para ser presentado socave el argumento anterior y, por lo tanto, el grafo de argumentos sea un árbol de una sola rama. Buscando tipos de protocolo más complejos que construyan tipos de gráficos de argumentos más complejos, es un paso obvio recurrir a: Definición 4.4. Un protocolo básico es multi-trayecto si todos los diálogos que se ajustan a él pueden construir gráficos de argumentos que son árboles. Pero, reflexionando, dado que cualquier gráfico con solo una rama también es un árbol: Proposición 4.4. Cualquier protocolo de un solo camino es una instancia de un protocolo de múltiples caminos. y, además: Proposición 4.5. Cualquier protocolo básico P es de múltiples caminos. Prueba. Inmediato a partir de la Proposición 4.1, por lo que la noción de un protocolo de múltiples rutas no tiene mucho impacto. Como resultado, distinguimos protocolos de múltiples rutas que permiten diálogos que pueden construir árboles con más de una rama como protocolos frondosos. Tenemos entonces: Proposición 4.6. Un protocolo básico P es frondoso si, para algún i, el conjunto de movimientos permitidos Mi en el movimiento i son todos relevantes a R1 o R2. Prueba. A partir de la Proposición 4.3 sabemos que si todos los movimientos son relevantes para R3, obtendremos un árbol con una rama, y a partir de la Proposición 4.1 sabemos que todos los protocolos básicos construirán un grafo de argumentos que es un árbol, por lo que si excluimos los movimientos relevantes para R3, obtendremos protocolos que pueden construir árboles de múltiples ramas. 1010 The Sixth Intl. Por supuesto, dado que, según la Proposición 4.2, cualquier movimiento que sea relevante en R3 también es relevante en R2 y posiblemente también lo sea en R1 (todo lo que nos dice la Proposición 4.2 es que no hay garantía de que lo sea), todo lo que nos dice la Proposición 4.6 es que los diálogos que se ajustan a protocolos ramificados pueden tener más de una rama. Todo lo que podemos hacer es identificar un límite en el número de ramas: Proposición 4.7. Consideremos un diálogo básico D que incluye m movimientos que no son relevantes para R3, y tiene un grafo de argumentación correspondiente AG. El número de ramas en AG es menor o igual a m + 1. Prueba. Dado que debe conectar un nodo al último nodo agregado a AG, un movimiento relevante para R3 solo puede extender una rama existente. Dado que no tienen la misma restricción, los movimientos relevantes de R1 y R2 pueden crear una nueva rama al conectarse a un nodo que no es el último nodo añadido. Cada movimiento de este tipo podría crear una nueva rama, y si lo hace, tendremos m ramas. Si hubo movimientos relevantes de R3 antes de cualquiera de estos movimientos que crean nuevas ramas, entonces estas m ramas son adicionales a la rama inicial creada por los movimientos relevantes de R3, y tenemos un máximo de m + 1 ramas posibles. Distinguimos entre protocolos ramificados y protocolos de múltiples rutas, y por lo tanto, entre la relevancia R1 y R2 y la relevancia R3, debido a los tipos de diálogo que impone la relevancia R3. En un diálogo en el que todos los movimientos deben ser relevantes para R3, el grafo de argumentación tiene una sola rama: el diálogo consiste en una secuencia de argumentos, cada uno de los cuales socava al anterior, y el último movimiento que se debe hacer es el que resuelve el diálogo. Esto, como veremos a continuación, significa que dicho diálogo solo permite un subconjunto de todos los movimientos que de otra manera serían posibles. 5. La discusión anterior sobre la diferencia entre los diálogos llevados a cabo bajo protocolos de un solo camino y de ramificación nos lleva a considerar lo que [18] llamó predeterminismo, pero ahora preferimos describirlo utilizando el término completitud. La idea de predeterminismo, tal como se describe en [18], captura la noción de que, bajo ciertas circunstancias, el resultado de un diálogo puede establecerse sin necesidad de tener realmente el diálogo: los agentes tienen tan poco margen para maniobrar retóricamente que si uno pudiera ver el contenido de todas las Σi de todos los αi ∈ A, se podría identificar el resultado de cualquier diálogo sobre un tema dado. Desarrollamos esta idea considerando cómo los grafos de argumentos construidos por diálogos bajo diferentes protocolos se comparan con diálogos completos de referencia. Comenzamos desarrollando ideas de lo que podría significar completo. Una definición razonable es la siguiente: Definición 5.1. Un diálogo básico D entre el conjunto de agentes A con un grafo de argumentación AG correspondiente es completo en cuanto al tema si ningún agente puede construir un argumento A que socave cualquier argumento A representado por un nodo en AG. El grafo de argumentación construido por un diálogo completo de temas se llama grafo de argumentación completo de temas y se denota AG(D)T. Suponiendo que los Σi no cambian durante el diálogo, lo cual es la suposición habitual en este tipo de diálogo. Un diálogo está completo en cuanto a tema cuando ningún agente puede añadir algo que esté directamente relacionado con el tema del diálogo. Algunos protocolos evitarán que los agentes realicen movimientos aunque el diálogo no esté completo en cuanto al tema. Para distinguir tales casos tenemos: Definición 5.2. Un diálogo básico D entre el conjunto de agentes A con un grafo de argumentación correspondiente AG es protocolo-completo bajo un protocolo P si ningún agente puede realizar una acción que añada un nodo al grafo de argumentación que esté permitido por P. El grafo de argumentación construido por un diálogo protocolo-completo se llama grafo de argumentación protocolo-completo y se denota AG(D)P. Claramente: Proposición 5.1. Cualquier diálogo D bajo un protocolo básico P es protocolo-completo si es completo en cuanto al tema. La afirmación contraria no se cumple en general. Prueba. Si D es completo en cuanto al tema, ningún agente puede realizar una acción que extienda el grafo de argumentación. Esto significa que ningún agente puede realizar una acción permitida por un protocolo básico, por lo que D también es completo en cuanto a protocolo. El recíproco no se cumple ya que algunos diálogos básicos (bajo un protocolo que solo permite movimientos relevantes de R3, por ejemplo) no permitirán ciertos movimientos (como la adición de un nodo que se conecta a la raíz del grafo de argumentación después de más de dos movimientos) que serían permitidos en un diálogo completo sobre el tema. Corolario 5.1. Para un diálogo básico D, AG(D)P es un subgrafo de AG(D)T. Obviamente, a partir de la definición de un subgrafo, el recíproco del Corolario 5.1 no se cumple en general. La distinción importante entre la completitud del tema y del protocolo es que la primera se determina puramente por el estado del diálogo, tal como se captura en el grafo de argumentación, y por lo tanto es independiente del protocolo, mientras que la última se determina enteramente por el protocolo. Cada vez que un diálogo termina en un estado de completitud de protocolo en lugar de completitud de tema, está terminando cuando los agentes aún tienen cosas que decir pero no pueden hacerlo porque el protocolo no se lo permite. Con estas definiciones de completitud, nuestra tarea es relacionar la completitud del tema, la propiedad que garantiza que los agentes puedan decir todo lo que tienen que decir en un diálogo que, en cierto sentido, es importante, con las nociones de relevancia que hemos desarrollado, las cuales determinan lo que los agentes pueden decir. Cuando necesitamos condiciones muy específicas para que los diálogos de protocolo sean completos en cuanto al tema, significa que los agentes tienen mucho margen para maniobrar retóricamente cuando esas condiciones no están presentes. Eso es, hay muchas formas en las que pueden dar por terminados los diálogos antes de que se haya dicho todo lo que se puede decir. Donde se requieren pocas condiciones, o las condiciones están ausentes, entonces los diálogos entre agentes con el mismo conocimiento siempre se desarrollarán de la misma manera, y la retórica no tiene cabida. Tenemos: Proposición 5.2. Un diálogo básico D completo de protocolo bajo un protocolo que solo permite movimientos relevantes para R3 será completo en cuanto al tema solo cuando AG(D)T tenga una sola rama en la que los nodos estén etiquetados en orden creciente desde la raíz. El Sexto Internacional. Conferencia Conjunta sobre Agentes Autónomos y Sistemas Multiagente (AAMAS 07) 1011 Prueba. Dado lo que sabemos sobre la relevancia de R3, la condición de que AG(D)P tenga una sola rama es obvia. Esta no es una condición suficiente por sí sola porque ciertos protocolos pueden evitar, a través de restricciones adicionales, como un estricto turno en un diálogo de múltiples partes, que todos los nodos en AG(D)T, que no están sujetos a tales restricciones, sean añadidos al grafo. Solo cuando AG(D)T incluye los nodos en el orden exacto en que se presentan los argumentos correspondientes, es necesario construir un grafo de argumentación completo sobre el tema. Dada la Proposición 5.1, estas son las condiciones bajo las cuales los diálogos llevados a cabo bajo la noción de relevancia R3 siempre estarán predeterminados, y dadas las condiciones restrictivas, parece que estos diálogos tienen mucho espacio para que la retórica juegue un papel. Para encontrar condiciones similares para diálogos compuestos por movimientos relevantes de R1 y R2, primero necesitamos distinguir entre ellos. Podemos hacer esto en términos de la estructura del grafo de argumentación: Proposición 5.3. Consideremos un diálogo básico D, con un grafo de argumentación AG que tiene una raíz r que denota un argumento A. Si el argumento A, denotado por el nodo v, es un movimiento relevante en R2 m, m no es relevante en R1 si y solo si: 1. hay dos nodos v y v en el camino entre v y r, y el argumento denotado por v se defiende a sí mismo contra el argumento denotado por v; o 2. hay un argumento A, denotado por el nodo v, que afecta al estado de A, y el camino desde v hasta r tiene uno o más nodos en común con el camino desde v hasta r. Demostración. Para la primera condición, considera que dado que AG es un árbol, v está conectado a r. Por lo tanto, hay una serie de relaciones de subestimación entre A y A, y esto corresponde a un camino a través de AG. Si este camino es la única rama en el árbol, entonces A afectará el estado de A a menos que la cadena de efectos sea interrumpida por un subcorte que no pueda cambiar el estado del argumento subcortado porque este se defiende a sí mismo. Para la segunda condición, al igual que para la primera, la única forma en que A no puede afectar el estado de A es si algo está bloqueando su influencia. Si esto no se debe a defenderse en contra, debe ser porque hay algún nodo u en el camino que representa un argumento cuyo estado está fijo de alguna manera, y eso debe significar que hay otra cadena de relaciones de subestimación, otra rama del árbol, que incide en u. Dado que esta segunda rama denota otra cadena de argumentos, y estos afectan el estado del argumento denotado por u, también deben afectar el estado de A. Cualquiera de estos es la A en la condición. Entonces, un movimiento m relevante para R2 no es relevante para R1 si su efecto está bloqueado porque un argumento aguas arriba no es lo suficientemente fuerte, o porque hay otra línea de argumentación que actualmente está determinando el estado del argumento en la raíz. Esto, a su vez, significa que si el efecto no se debe a defenderse contra, entonces hay un movimiento alternativo que es relevante para R1, un movimiento que socava A en la segunda condición anterior. Ahora podemos mostrar 5 Aunque si el agente en cuestión puede realizar tal movimiento es otra pregunta. Proposición 5.4. Un diálogo básico D completo de protocolo siempre será completo en tema bajo un protocolo que solo incluya movimientos relevantes de R2 y permita que se realice cada movimiento relevante de R2. La restricción en las reglas relevantes para R2 es exactamente la de completitud del tema, por lo que un diálogo que solo tenga movimientos relevantes para R2 continuará hasta que se hayan presentado todos los argumentos que cualquier agente pueda hacer. Dado esto, y lo que revelamos sobre la relevancia R1 en la Proposición 5.3, podemos ver que: Proposición 5.5. Un diálogo básico D completo en protocolo bajo un protocolo que solo incluye movimientos relevantes R1 será completo en tema si AG(D)T: 1. no incluye ninguna ruta con nodos adyacentes v, denotando A, y v, denotando A, tal que A socava a A y A es más fuerte que A; y 2. es tal que los nodos en cada rama tienen índices consecutivos y ningún nodo con grado mayor a dos está a un número impar de arcos de un nodo hoja. Prueba. La primera condición descarta la primera condición en la Proposición 5.3, y la segunda trata la situación que conduce a la segunda condición en la Proposición 5.3. La segunda condición asegura que cada rama se construya por completo antes de que se agregue una nueva rama, y cuando se agrega una nueva rama, el argumento que se socava como parte de la adición será aceptable, por lo que la adición cambiará el estado del argumento designado por ese nodo, y por lo tanto, la raíz. Con estas condiciones, se permitirá cada movimiento necesario para construir AG(D)T y así el diálogo estará completo en cuanto se hayan completado todos los movimientos. La segunda parte de este resultado solo identifica una posible forma de asegurar que se cumpla la segunda condición en la Proposición 5.3, por lo que el recíproco de este resultado no se cumple. Sin embargo, lo que tenemos es suficiente para responder la pregunta sobre la predeterminación con la que comenzamos. Para que los diálogos estén predeterminados, se deben realizar todos los movimientos relevantes de R2. En tales casos, cada diálogo es completo en cuanto al tema. Si no requerimos que se realicen todos los movimientos relevantes para R2, entonces hay margen para la retórica: la forma en que se presentan las líneas alternativas de argumentación se convierte en un problema. Si los movimientos se ven obligados a ser relevantes para R3, entonces hay un amplio margen para el juego retórico. 6. RESUMEN Este artículo ha estudiado las diferentes ideas de relevancia en el diálogo basado en argumentos, identificando la relación entre estas ideas y mostrando cómo pueden impactar en la medida en que los agentes eligen movimientos en un diálogo, lo que algunos autores han llamado la estrategia y tácticas de un diálogo. Esto amplía el trabajo existente sobre la relevancia, como [3, 15], al mostrar cómo diferentes nociones de relevancia pueden tener un efecto en el resultado de un diálogo, en particular cuando hacen que el resultado esté predeterminado. Esta conexión amplía el trabajo de [18], que consideró el resultado del diálogo, pero no llegó a identificar las condiciones bajo las cuales está predeterminado. Hay dos formas en las que actualmente estamos intentando extender este trabajo, ambas de las cuales generalizarán los resultados y ampliarán su aplicabilidad. Primero, queremos relajar las restricciones que 1012 The Sixth Intl. En la Conferencia Conjunta sobre Agentes Autónomos y Sistemas Multiagente (AAMAS 07) hemos impuesto la exclusión de movimientos que atacan varios argumentos (sin los cuales el grafo de argumentos puede estar múltiplemente conectado) y la exclusión de movimientos prevenidos, sin los cuales el grafo de argumentos puede tener ciclos. Segundo, queremos extender las ideas de relevancia para hacer frente a movimientos que no solo añaden argumentos de subestimación, sino también argumentos de apoyo, teniendo en cuenta así los marcos de argumentación bipolares [5]. original_annotated_sentences: On the relevance of utterances in formal inter-agent dialogues Simon Parsons1 Peter McBurney2 1 Department of Computer & Information Science Brooklyn College, City University of New York Brooklyn NY 11210 USA {parsons,sklar}@sci.brooklyn.cuny.edu Elizabeth Sklar1 Michael Wooldridge2 2 Department of Computer Science University of Liverpool Liverpool L69 7ZF UK {p.j.mcburney,m.j.wooldridge}@csc.liv.ac.uk ABSTRACT Work on argumentation-based dialogue has defined frameworks within which dialogues can be carried out, established protocols that govern dialogues, and studied different properties of dialogues.
This work has established the space in which agents are permitted to interact through dialogues.

Recently, there has been increasing interest in the mechanisms agents might use to choose how to act - the rhetorical manoeuvring that they use to navigate through the space defined by the rules of the dialogue.
Key in such considerations is the idea of relevance, since a usual requirement is that agents stay focussed on the subject of the dialogue and only make relevant remarks.
Here we study several notions of relevance, showing how they can be related to both the rules for carrying out dialogues and to rhetorical manoeuvring.
Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.11 [Artificial Intelligence]: Distributed Artificial Intelligence: Coherence & co-ordination; languages & structures; multiagent systems.
General Terms Design, languages, theory. 1.
INTRODUCTION Finding ways for agents to reach agreements in multiagent systems is an area of active research.
One mechanism for achieving agreement is through the use of argumentation - where one agent tries to convince another agent of something during the course of some dialogue.

Early examples of argumentation-based approaches to multiagent agreement include the work of Dignum et al. [7], Kraus [14], Parsons and Jennings [16], Reed [23], Schroeder et al. [25] and Sycara [26].
The work of Walton and Krabbe [27], popularised in the multiagent systems community by Reed [23], has been particularly influential in the field of argumentation-based dialogue.
This work influenced the field in a number of ways, perhaps most deeply in framing multi-agent interactions as dialogue games in the tradition of Hamblin [13].

Viewing dialogues in this way, as in [2, 21], provides a powerful framework for analysing the formal properties of dialogues, and for identifying suitable protocols under which dialogues can be conducted [18, 20].
The dialogue game view overlaps with work on conversation policies (see, for example, [6, 10]), but differs in considering the entire dialogue rather than dialogue segments.
In this paper, we extend the work of [18] by considering the role of relevance - the relationship between utterances in a dialogue.

Relevance is a topic of increasing interest in argumentation-based dialogue because it relates to the scope that an agent has for applying strategic manoeuvering to obtain the outcomes that it requires [19, 22, 24].
Our work identifes the limits on such rhetorical manoeuvering, showing when it can and cannot have an effect. 2.
BACKGROUND We begin by introducing the formal system of argumentation that underpins our approach, as well as the corresponding terminology and notation, all taken from [2, 8, 17].
A dialogue is a sequence of messages passed between two or more members of a set of agents A.
An agent α maintains a knowledge base, Σα, containing formulas of a propositional language L and having no deductive closure.
Agent α also maintains the set of its past utterances, called the commitment store, CSα.
We refer to this as an agents public knowledge, since it contains information that is shared with other agents.
In contrast, the contents of Σα are private to α.
Note that in the description that follows, we assume that is the classical inference relation, that ≡ stands for logical equivalence, and we use Δ to denote all the information available to an agent.
Thus in a dialogue between two agents α and β, Δα = Σα ∪ CSα ∪ CSβ, so the commitment store CSα can be loosely thought of as a subset of Δα consisting of the assertions that have been made public.
In some dialogue games, such as those in [18] anything in CSα is either in Σα or can be derived from it.
In other dialogue games, such as 1006 978-81-904262-7-5 (RPS) c 2007 IFAAMAS those in [2], CSα may contain things that cannot be derived from Σα.
Definition 2.1.

An argument A is a pair (S, p) where p is a formula of L and S a subset of Δ such that (i) S is consistent; (ii) S p; and (iii) S is minimal, so no proper subset of S satisfying both (1) and (2) exists.
S is called the support of A, written S = Support(A) and p is the conclusion of A, written p = Conclusion(A).
Thus we talk of p being supported by the argument (S, p).

In general, since Δ may be inconsistent, arguments in A(Δ), the set of all arguments which can be made from Δ, may conflict, and we make this idea precise with the notion of undercutting: Definition 2.2.
Let A1 and A2 be arguments in A(Δ).
A1 undercuts A2 iff ∃¬p ∈ Support(A2) such that p ≡ Conclusion(A1).
In other words, an argument is undercut if and only if there is another argument which has as its conclusion the negation of an element of the support for the first argument.
To capture the fact that some beliefs are more strongly held than others, we assume that any set of beliefs has a preference order over it.

We consider all information available to an agent, Δ, to be stratified into non-overlapping subsets Δ1, . . . , Δn such that beliefs in Δi are all equally preferred and are preferred over elements in Δj where i > j.

The preference level of a nonempty subset S ⊂ Δ, where different elements s ∈ S may belong to different layers Δi, is valued at the highest numbered layer which has a member in S and is referred to as level(S).
In other words, S is only as strong as its weakest member.
Note that the strength of a belief as used in this context is a separate concept from the notion of support discussed earlier.
Definition 2.3.
Let A1 and A2 be arguments in A(Δ).
A1 is preferred to A2 according to Pref , A1 Pref A2, iff level(Support(A1)) > level(Support(A2)).
If A1 is preferred to A2, we say that A1 is stronger than A2.
We can now define the argumentation system we will use: Definition 2.4.

An argumentation system is a triple: A(Δ), Undercut, Pref such that: • A(Δ) is a set of the arguments built from Δ, • Undercut is a binary relation representing the defeat relationship between arguments, Undercut ⊆ A(Δ) × A(Δ), and • Pref is a pre-ordering on A(Δ) × A(Δ).
The preference order makes it possible to distinguish different types of relations between arguments: Definition 2.5.
Let A1, A2 be two arguments of A(Δ). • If A2 undercuts A1 then A1 defends itself against A2 iff A1 Pref A2.

Otherwise, A1 does not defend itself. • A set of arguments A defends A1 iff for every A2 that undercuts A1, where A1 does not defend itself against A2, then there is some A3 ∈ A such that A3 undercuts A2 and A2 does not defend itself against A3.
We write AUndercut,Pref to denote the set of all non-undercut arguments and arguments defending themselves against all their undercutting arguments.

The set A(Δ) of acceptable arguments of the argumentation system A(Δ), Undercut, Pref is [1] the least fixpoint of a function F: A ⊆ A(Δ) F(A) = {(S, p) ∈ A(Δ) | (S, p) is defended by A} Definition 2.6.

The set of acceptable arguments for an argumentation system A(Δ), Undercut, Pref is recursively defined as: A(Δ) = [ Fi≥0(∅) = AUndercut,Pref ∪ h[ Fi≥1(AUndercut,Pref ) i An argument is acceptable if it is a member of the acceptable set, and a proposition is acceptable if it is the conclusion of an acceptable argument.
An acceptable argument is one which is, in some sense, proven since all the arguments which might undermine it are themselves undermined.
Definition 2.7.
If there is an acceptable argument for a proposition p, then the status of p is accepted, while if there is not an acceptable argument for p, the status of p is not accepted.
Argument A is said to affect the status of another argument A if changing the status of A will change the status of A . 3.

DIALOGUES Systems like those described in [2, 18], lay down sets of locutions that agents can make to put forward propositions and the arguments that support them, and protocols that define precisely which locutions can be made at which points in the dialogue.
We are not concerned with such a level of detail here.
Instead we are interested in the interplay between arguments that agents put forth.
As a result, we will consider only that agents are allowed to put forward arguments.

We do not discuss the detail of the mechanism that is used to put these arguments forward - we just assume that arguments of the form (S, p) are inserted into an agents commitment store where they are then visible to other agents.
We then have a typical definition of a dialogue: Definition 3.1.
A dialogue D is a sequence of moves: m1, m2, . . . , mn.
A given move mi is a pair α, Ai where Ai is an argument that α places into its commitment store CSα.
Moves in an argumentation-based dialogue typically attack moves that have been made previously.

While, in general, a dialogue can include moves that undercut several arguments, in the remainder of this paper, we will only consider dialogues that put forward moves that undercut at most one argument.
For now we place no additional constraints on the moves that make up a dialogue.
Later we will see how different restrictions on moves lead to different kinds of dialogue.

As indicated earlier, their choice is typically limited by a protocol.
If we write the sequence of n moves m1, m2, . . . , mn as mn, and denote the empty sequence as m0, then we can define a profocol in the following way: Definition 3.2.

A protocol P is a function on a sequence of moves mi in a dialogue D that, for all i ≥ 0, identifies a set of possible moves Mi+1 from which the mi+1th move may be drawn: P : mi → Mi+1 In other words, for our purposes here, at every point in a dialogue, a protocol determines a set of possible moves that agents may make as part of the dialogue.

If a dialogue D always picks its moves m from the set M identified by protocol P, then D is said to conform to P. Even if a dialogue conforms to a protocol, it is typically the case that the agent engaging in the dialogue has to make a choice of move - it has to choose which of the moves in M to make.
This excercise of choice is what we refer to as an agents use of rhetoric (in its oratorical sense of influencing the thought and conduct of an audience).
Some of our results will give a sense of how much scope an agent has to exercise rhetoric under different protocols.
As arguments are placed into commitment stores, and hence become public, agents can determine the relationships between them.
In general, after several moves in a dialogue, some arguments will undercut others.

RELEVANCE Most work on dialogues is concerned with what we might call coherent dialogues, that is dialogues in which the participants are, as in the work of Walton and Krabbe [27], focused on resolving some question through the dialogue2 To capture this coherence, it seems we need a notion of relevance to constrain the statements made by agents.
Here we study three notions of relevance: Definition 4.1.

Consider a dialogue D, consisting of a sequence of moves mi, with a corresponding argument
graph
AG.
The move mi+1, i > 1, is said to be relevant if one or more of the following hold: R1 Making mi+1 will change the status of the argument denoted by the first node of AG.
R2 Making mi+1 will add a node vi+1 that is connected to the first node of AG.
R3 Making mi+1 will add a node vi+1 that is connected to the last node to be added to AG.
R2-relevance is the form of relevance defined by [3] in their study of strategic and tactical reasoning3 .
R1-relevance was suggested by the notion used in [15], and though it differs somewhat from that suggested there, we believe it captures the essence of its predecessor.

Note that we only define relevance for the second move of the dialogue onwards because the first move is taken to identify the subject of the dialogue, that is, the central question that the dialogue is intended to answer, and hence it must be relevant to the dialogue, no matter what it is.
In assuming this, we focus our attention on the same kind of dialogues as [18].
We can think of relevance as enforcing a form of parsimony on a dialogue - it prevents agents from making statements that do not bear on the current state of the dialogue.
This promotes efficiency, in the sense of limiting the number of moves in the dialogue, and, as in [15], prevents agents revealing information that they might better keep hidden.
Another form of parsimony is to insist that agents are not allowed to put forward arguments that will be undercut by arguments that have already been made during the dialogue.
We therefore distinguish such arguments. 2 See [11, 12] for examples of dialogues where this is not the case. 3 We consider such reasoning sub-types of rhetoric.
Definition 4.2.

Consider a dialogue D, consisting of a sequence of moves mi, with a corresponding argument
graph
AG.
The move mi+1 and the argument it puts forward, Ai+1, are both said to be pre-empted, if Ai+1 is undercut by some A ∈ Ai.

We use the term pre-empted because if such an argument is put forward, it can seem as though another agent anticipated the argument being made, and already made an argument that would render it useless.
In the rest of this paper, we will only deal with protocols that permit moves that are relevant, in any of the senses introduced above, and are not allowed to be pre-empted.
We call such protocols basic protocols, and dialogues carried out under such protocols basic dialogues.

The argument
graph
of a basic dialogue is somewhat restricted.
Proposition 4.1.

Consider a basic dialogue D. The argumentation
graph
AG that corresponds to D is a tree with a single root.
Proof.

Recall that Definition 3.3 requires only that AG be a directed
graph
.
To show that it is a tree, we have to show that it is acyclic and connected.

That the
graph
is connected follows from the construction of the
graph
under a protocol that enforces relevance.
If the notion of relevance is R3, each move adds a node that is connected to the previous node.

If the notion of relevance is R2, then every move adds a node that is connected to the root, and thus is connected to some node in the
graph
.
If the notion of relevance is R1, then every move has to change the status of the argument denoted by the root.

Proposition 3.1 tells us that to affect the status of an argument A , the node v representing the argument A that is effecting the change has to be connected to v , the node representing A , and so it follows that every new node added as a result of an R1relevant move will be connected to the argumentation
graph

Thus AG is connected.

Since a basic dialogue does not allow moves that are preempted, every edge that is added during construction is directed from the node that is added to one already in the
graph
(thus denoting that the argument A denoted by the added node, v, undercuts the argument A denoted by the node to which the connection is made, v , rather than the other way around).

Since every edge that is added is directed from the new node to the rest of the
graph
, there can be no cycles.
Thus AG is a tree.
To show that AG has a single root, consider its construction from the initial node.

After m1 the
graph
has one node, v1 that is both a root and a leaf.

After m2, the
graph
is two nodes connected by an edge, and v1 is now a root and not a leaf. v2 is a leaf and not a root.
However the third node is added, the argument earlier in this proof demonstrates that there will be a directed edge from it to some other node, making it a leaf.
Thus v1 will always be the only root.

The ruling out of pre-empted moves means that v1 will never cease to be a root, and so the argumentation
graph
will always have one root.

Since every argumentation
graph
constructed by a basic dialogue is a tree with a single root, this means that the first node of every argumentation
graph
is the root.
Although these results are straightforward to obtain, they allow us to show how the notions of relevance are related.

What is most interesting is not so much the results but why they hold, since this reveals some aspects of the interplay between relevance and the structure of argument graphs.

For example, to restate a case from the proof of Proposition 4.2, a move that is R3-relevant by definition has to add a node to the argument

It turns out that we can exploit the interplay between structure and relevance that Propositions 4.1 and 4.2 have started to illuminate to establish relationships between the protocols that govern dialogues and the argument graphs constructed during such dialogues.

To do this we need to define protocols in such a way that they refer to the structure of the

We have: Definition 4.3.
A protocol is single-path if all dialogues that conform to it construct argument graphs that have only one branch.
Proposition 4.3.
A basic protocol P is single-path if, for all i, the set of permitted moves Mi at move i are all R3relevant.
The converse does not hold.
Proof.

R3-relevance requires that every node added to the argument

be connected to the previous node.
Starting from the first node this recursively constructs a tree with just one branch, and the relationship holds.

The converse does not hold because even if one or more moves in the protocol are R1- or R2-relevant, it may be the case that, because of an agents rhetorical choice or because of its knowledge, every argument that is chosen to be put forward will undercut the previous argument and so the argument
graph
is a one-branch tree.

Any single-path protocol is an instance of a multi-path protocol. and, furthermore: Proposition 4.5.
Any basic protocol P is multi-path.
Proof.
Immediate from Proposition 4.1 So the notion of a multi-path protocol does not have much traction.
As a result we distinguish multi-path protocols that permit dialogues that can construct trees that have more than one branch as bushy protocols.

A basic protocol P is bushy if, for some i, the set of permitted moves Mi at move i are all R1- or R2-relevant.
Proof.

From Proposition 4.3 we know that if all moves are R3-relevant then well get a tree with one branch, and from Proposition 4.1 we know that all basic protocols will build an argument

All we can do is to identify a bound on the number of branches: Proposition 4.7.

Consider a basic dialogue D that includes m moves that are not R3-relevant, and has a corresponding argumentation
graph
AG.
The number of branches in AG is less than or equal to m + 1.
Proof.
Since it must connect a node to the last node added to AG, an R3-relevant move can only extend an existing branch.
Since they do not have the same restriction, R1 and R2-relevant moves may create a new branch by connecting to a node that is not the last node added.
Every such move could create a new branch, and if they do, we will have m branches.

If there were R3-relevant moves before any of these new-branch-creating moves, then these m branches are in addition to the initial branch created by the R3-relevant moves, and we have a maximum of m + 1 possible branches.
We distinguish bushy protocols from multi-path protocols, and hence R1- and R2-relevance from R3-relevance, because of the kinds of dialogue that R3-relevance enforces.

In a dialogue in which all moves must be R3-relevant, the argumentation
graph
has a single branch - the dialogue consists of a sequence of arguments each of which undercuts the previous one and the last move to be made is the one that settles the dialogue.
This, as we will see next, means that such a dialogue only allows a subset of all the moves that would otherwise be possible. 5.

COMPLETENESS The above discussion of the difference between dialogues carried out under single-path and bushy protocols brings us to the consideration of what [18] called predeterminism, but we now prefer to describe using the term completeness.

The idea of predeterminism, as described in [18], captures the notion that, under some circumstances, the result of a dialogue can be established without actually having the dialogue - the agents have sufficiently little room for rhetorical manoeuver that were one able to see the contents of all the Σi of all the αi ∈ A, one would be able to identify the outcome of any dialogue on a given subject4 .
We develop this idea by considering how the argument graphs constructed by dialogues under different protocols compare to benchmark complete dialogues.
We start by developing ideas of what complete might mean.
One reasonable definition is that: Definition 5.1.

A basic dialogue D between the set of agents A with a corresponding argumentation
graph
AG is topic-complete if no agent can construct an argument A that undercuts any argument A represented by a node in AG.

The argumentation
graph
constructed by a topic-complete dialogue is called a topic-complete argumentation
graph
and is denoted AG(D)T . 4 Assuming that the Σi do not change during the dialogue, which is the usual assumption in this kind of dialogue.
A dialogue is topic-complete when no agent can add anything that is directly connected to the subject of the dialogue.
Some protocols will prevent agents from making moves even though the dialogue is not topic-complete.
To distinguish such cases we have: Definition 5.2.

A basic dialogue D between the set of agents A with a corresponding argumentation
graph
AG is protocol-complete under a protocol P if no agent can make a move that adds a node to the argumentation
graph
that is permitted by P. The argumentation graph constructed by a protocol-complete dialogue is called a protocol-complete argumentation graph and is denoted AG(D)P .
Clearly: Proposition 5.1.
Any dialogue D under a basic protocol P is protocol-complete if it is topic-complete.
The converse does not hold in general.
Proof.

If D is topic-complete, no agent can make a move that will extend the argumentation
graph
.
This means that no agent can make a move that is permitted by a basic protocol, and so D is also protocol complete.

The converse does not hold since some basic dialogues (under a protocol that only permits R3-relevant moves, for example) will not permit certain moves (like the addition of a node that connects to the root of the argumentation
graph
after more than two moves) that would be allowed in a topiccomplete dialogue.
Corollary 5.1.

For a basic dialogue D, AG(D)P is a sub-
graph
of AG(D)T .

Obviously, from the definition of a sub-
graph
, the converse of Corollary 5.1 does not hold in general.

The important distinction between topic- and protocolcompleteness is that the former is determined purely by the state of the dialogue - as captured by the argumentation
graph
- and is thus independent of the protocol, while the latter is determined entirely by the protocol.
Any time that a dialogue ends in a state of protocol-completeness rather than topic completeness, it is ending when agents still have things to say but cant because the protocol wont allow them to.

With these definitions of completeness, our task is to relate topic-completeness - the property that ensures that agents can say everything that they have to say in a dialogue that is, in some sense, important - to the notions of relevance we have developed - which determine what agents are allowed to say.
When we need very specific conditions to make protocol-complete dialogues topic-complete, it means that agents have lots of room for rhetorical maneouver when those conditions are not in force.
That is there are many ways they can bring dialogues to a close before everything that can be said has been said.
Where few conditions are required, or conditions are absent, then dialogues between agents with the same knowledge will always play out the same way, and rhetoric has no place.
We have: Proposition 5.2.

A protocol-complete basic dialogue D under a protocol which only allows R3-relevant moves will be topic-complete only when AG(D)T has a single branch in which the nodes are labelled in increasing order from the root.

Proposition 5.4.
A protocol-complete basic dialogue D will always be topic-complete under a protocol which only includes R2-relevant moves and allows every R2-relevant move to be made.

The restriction on R2-relevant rules is exactly that for topiccompleteness, so a dialogue that has only R2-relevant moves will continue until every argument that any agent can make has been put forward.
Given this, and what we revealed about R1-relevance in Proposition 5.3, we can see that: Proposition 5.5.

A protocol-complete basic dialogue D under a protocol which only includes R1-relevant moves will be topic-complete if AG(D)T : 1. includes no path with adjacent nodes v, denoting A, and v , denoting A , such that A undercuts A and A is stronger that A; and 2. is such that the nodes in every branch have consecutive indices and no node with degree greater than two is an odd number of arcs from a leaf node.
Proof.
The first condition rules out the first condition in Proposition 5.3, and the second deals with the situation that leads to the second condition in Proposition 5.3.

The second condition ensures that each branch is constructed in full before any new branch is added, and when a new branch is added, the argument that is undercut as part of the addition will be acceptable, and so the addition will change the status of the argument denoted by that node, and hence the root.
With these conditions, every move required to construct AG(D)T will be permitted and so the dialogue will be topic-complete when every move has been completed.
The second part of this result only identifies one possible way to ensure that the second condition in Proposition 5.3 is met, so the converse of this result does not hold.
However, what we have is sufficient to answer the question about predetermination that we started with.
For dialogues to be predetermined, every move that is R2-relevant must be made.
In such cases every dialogue is topic complete.
If we do not require that all R2-relevant moves are made, then there is some room for rhetoric - the way in which alternative lines of argument are presented becomes an issue.
If moves are forced to be R3-relevant, then there is considerable room for rhetorical play. 6.

SUMMARY This paper has studied the different ideas of relevance in argumentation-based dialogue, identifying the relationship between these ideas, and showing how they can impact the extent to which the way that agents choose moves in a dialogue - what some authors have called the strategy and tactics of a dialogue.

This extends existing work on relvance, such as [3, 15] by showing how different notions of relevance can have an effect on the outcome of a dialogue, in particular when they render the outcome predetermined.
This connection extends the work of [18] which considered dialogue outcome, but stopped short of identifying the conditions under which it is predetermined.
There are two ways we are currently trying to extend this work, both of which will generalise the results and extend its applicability.
First, we want to relax the restrictions that 1012 The Sixth Intl.

graph

graph
can have cycles.

Second, we want to extend the ideas of relevance to cope with moves that do not only add undercutting arguments, but also supporting arguments, thus taking account of bipolar argumentation frameworks [5].

Sobre la relevancia de las enunciaciones en diálogos formales entre agentes Simon Parsons1 Peter McBurney2 1 Departamento de Ciencias de la Computación e Informática Brooklyn College, City University of New York Brooklyn NY 11210 USA {parsons,sklar}@sci.brooklyn.cuny.edu Elizabeth Sklar1 Michael Wooldridge2 2 Departamento de Ciencias de la Computación Universidad de Liverpool Liverpool L69 7ZF UK {p.j.mcburney,m.j.wooldridge}@csc.liv.ac.uk RESUMEN El trabajo sobre diálogos basados en argumentación ha definido marcos dentro de los cuales los diálogos pueden llevarse a cabo, establecido protocolos que rigen los diálogos y estudiado diferentes propiedades de los diálogos. Este trabajo ha establecido el espacio en el que los agentes tienen permitido interactuar a través de diálogos. Recientemente, ha habido un creciente interés en los mecanismos que los agentes podrían utilizar para elegir cómo actuar, las maniobras retóricas que utilizan para navegar a través del espacio definido por las reglas del diálogo. La clave en tales consideraciones es la idea de relevancia, ya que un requisito habitual es que los agentes se mantengan enfocados en el tema del diálogo y solo hagan observaciones relevantes. Aquí estudiamos varias nociones de relevancia, mostrando cómo pueden estar relacionadas tanto con las reglas para llevar a cabo diálogos como con maniobras retóricas. Categorías y Descriptores de Asignaturas I.2.11 [Inteligencia Artificial]: Inteligencia Artificial Distribuida: Coherencia y coordinación; lenguajes y estructuras; sistemas multiagente. Términos generales Diseño, lenguajes, teoría. 1. INTRODUCCIÓN Encontrar formas para que los agentes lleguen a acuerdos en sistemas multiagentes es un área de investigación activa. Un mecanismo para lograr un acuerdo es a través del uso de la argumentación, donde un agente intenta convencer a otro agente de algo durante el transcurso de un diálogo. Los primeros ejemplos de enfoques basados en argumentación para acuerdos multiagentes incluyen el trabajo de Dignum et al. [7], Kraus [14], Parsons y Jennings [16], Reed [23], Schroeder et al. [25] y Sycara [26]. El trabajo de Walton y Krabbe [27], popularizado en la comunidad de sistemas multiagentes por Reed [23], ha sido particularmente influyente en el campo del diálogo basado en argumentación. Este trabajo influyó en el campo de varias maneras, quizás más profundamente al enmarcar las interacciones multiagente como juegos de diálogo en la tradición de Hamblin [13]. Al ver los diálogos de esta manera, como en [2, 21], se proporciona un marco poderoso para analizar las propiedades formales de los diálogos y para identificar protocolos adecuados bajo los cuales los diálogos pueden ser conducidos [18, 20]. La vista del juego de diálogo se superpone con el trabajo en políticas de conversación (ver, por ejemplo, [6, 10]), pero difiere al considerar todo el diálogo en lugar de segmentos de diálogo. En este artículo, ampliamos el trabajo de [18] al considerar el papel de la relevancia, es decir, la relación entre enunciados en un diálogo. La relevancia es un tema de creciente interés en el diálogo basado en argumentación porque se relaciona con el alcance que un agente tiene para aplicar maniobras estratégicas y obtener los resultados que requiere [19, 22, 24]. Nuestro trabajo identifica los límites de dicho juego retórico, mostrando cuándo puede y no puede tener un efecto. FONDO Comenzamos presentando el sistema formal de argumentación que sustenta nuestro enfoque, así como la terminología y notación correspondientes, tomadas de [2, 8, 17]. Un diálogo es una secuencia de mensajes intercambiados entre dos o más miembros de un conjunto de agentes A. Un agente α mantiene una base de conocimiento, Σα, que contiene fórmulas de un lenguaje proposicional L y no tiene cierre deductivo. El agente α también mantiene el conjunto de sus enunciados pasados, llamado almacén de compromisos, CSα. Nos referimos a esto como el conocimiento público de los agentes, ya que contiene información que se comparte con otros agentes. Por el contrario, el contenido de Σα es privado para α. Ten en cuenta que en la descripción que sigue, asumimos que es la relación de inferencia clásica, que ≡ representa la equivalencia lógica, y usamos Δ para denotar toda la información disponible para un agente. Por lo tanto, en un diálogo entre dos agentes α y β, Δα = Σα ∪ CSα ∪ CSβ, por lo que la tienda de compromisos CSα puede considerarse vagamente como un subconjunto de Δα que consiste en las afirmaciones que se han hecho públicas. En algunos juegos de diálogo, como los de [18], cualquier cosa en CSα está en Σα o puede derivarse de ella. En otros juegos de diálogo, como 1006 978-81-904262-7-5 (RPS) c 2007 IFAAMAS, aquellos en [2], CSα puede contener cosas que no pueden derivarse de Σα. Definición 2.1. Un argumento A es un par (S, p) donde p es una fórmula de L y S es un subconjunto de Δ tal que (i) S es consistente; (ii) S p; y (iii) S es minimal, de modo que no existe un subconjunto propio de S que satisfaga tanto (1) como (2). S se llama el soporte de A, escrito S = Soporte(A) y p es la conclusión de A, escrito p = Conclusión(A). Así hablamos de que p es respaldado por el argumento (S, p). En general, dado que Δ puede ser inconsistente, los argumentos en A(Δ), el conjunto de todos los argumentos que se pueden hacer a partir de Δ, pueden entrar en conflicto, y precisamos esta idea con el concepto de subversión: Definición 2.2. En otras palabras, un argumento se ve socavado si y solo si hay otro argumento cuya conclusión sea la negación de un elemento del respaldo del primer argumento. Para capturar el hecho de que algunas creencias se mantienen con más fuerza que otras, asumimos que cualquier conjunto de creencias tiene un orden de preferencia sobre ellas. Consideramos que toda la información disponible para un agente, Δ, está estratificada en subconjuntos no superpuestos Δ1, . . . , Δn, de modo que las creencias en Δi son todas igualmente preferidas y son preferidas sobre los elementos en Δj donde i > j. El nivel de preferencia de un subconjunto no vacío S ⊂ Δ, donde diferentes elementos s ∈ S pueden pertenecer a diferentes capas Δi, se valora en la capa con el número más alto que tenga un miembro en S y se denomina nivel(S). En otras palabras, S solo es tan fuerte como su miembro más débil. Ten en cuenta que la fuerza de una creencia, tal como se utiliza en este contexto, es un concepto separado de la noción de apoyo discutida anteriormente. Definición 2.3. Sean A1 y A2 argumentos en A(Δ). A1 es preferido a A2 según Pref, A1 Pref A2, si y solo si el nivel(Support(A1)) > nivel(Support(A2)). Si A1 es preferido a A2, decimos que A1 es más fuerte que A2. Ahora podemos definir el sistema de argumentación que utilizaremos: Definición 2.4. Un sistema de argumentación es un triple: A(Δ), Subversión, Pref tal que: • A(Δ) es un conjunto de argumentos construidos a partir de Δ, • Subversión es una relación binaria que representa la relación de derrota entre argumentos, Subversión ⊆ A(Δ) × A(Δ), y • Pref es un preorden en A(Δ) × A(Δ). El orden de preferencia permite distinguir diferentes tipos de relaciones entre argumentos: Definición 2.5. Sean A1, A2 dos argumentos de A(Δ). • Si A2 socava a A1, entonces A1 se defiende contra A2 si y solo si A1 Pref A2. De lo contrario, A1 no se defiende a sí mismo. • Un conjunto de argumentos A defiende a A1 si para cada A2 que socava a A1, donde A1 no se defiende a sí mismo contra A2, entonces hay algún A3 ∈ A tal que A3 socava a A2 y A2 no se defiende a sí mismo contra A3. Escribimos AUndercut, Pref para denotar el conjunto de todos los argumentos no subestimados y los argumentos que se defienden contra todos sus argumentos subestimados. El conjunto A(Δ) de argumentos aceptables del sistema de argumentación A(Δ), Undercut, Pref es [1] el punto fijo menor de una función F: A ⊆ A(Δ) F(A) = {(S, p) ∈ A(Δ) | (S, p) es defendido por A} Definición 2.6. El conjunto de argumentos aceptables para un sistema de argumentación A(Δ), Undercut, Pref se define recursivamente como: A(Δ) = [ Fi≥0(∅) = AUndercut,Pref ∪ h[ Fi≥1(AUndercut,Pref ) i Un argumento es aceptable si es miembro del conjunto aceptable, y una proposición es aceptable si es la conclusión de un argumento aceptable. Un argumento aceptable es aquel que, en cierto sentido, está probado ya que todos los argumentos que podrían socavarlo son a su vez socavados. Definición 2.7. Si hay un argumento aceptable para una proposición p, entonces el estatus de p es aceptado, mientras que si no hay un argumento aceptable para p, el estatus de p no es aceptado. Se dice que el argumento A afecta el estado de otro argumento A si cambiar el estado de A cambiará el estado de A. Sistemas de DIÁLOGOS como los descritos en [2, 18], establecen conjuntos de locuciones que los agentes pueden hacer para presentar proposiciones y los argumentos que las respaldan, y protocolos que definen precisamente qué locuciones se pueden hacer en qué puntos del diálogo. Aquí no nos preocupa ese nivel de detalle. En cambio, estamos interesados en la interacción entre los argumentos que los agentes presentan. Como resultado, consideraremos únicamente que los agentes pueden presentar argumentos. No discutimos el detalle del mecanismo que se utiliza para presentar estos argumentos, simplemente asumimos que los argumentos de la forma (S, p) se insertan en la tienda de compromisos de un agente donde luego son visibles para otros agentes. Tenemos entonces una definición típica de un diálogo: Definición 3.1. Un diálogo D es una secuencia de movimientos: m1, m2, . . . , mn. Si bien, en general, un diálogo puede incluir movimientos que socavan varios argumentos, en el resto de este documento, solo consideraremos diálogos que presenten movimientos que socaven como máximo un argumento. Por ahora no imponemos restricciones adicionales a los movimientos que conforman un diálogo. Más tarde veremos cómo diferentes restricciones en los movimientos conducen a diferentes tipos de diálogo. Como se indicó anteriormente, su elección suele estar limitada por un protocolo. original_annotated_sentences: On the relevance of utterances in formal inter-agent dialogues Simon Parsons1 Peter McBurney2 1 Department of Computer & Information Science Brooklyn College, City University of New York Brooklyn NY 11210 USA {parsons,sklar}@sci.brooklyn.cuny.edu Elizabeth Sklar1 Michael Wooldridge2 2 Department of Computer Science University of Liverpool Liverpool L69 7ZF UK {p.j.mcburney,m.j.wooldridge}@csc.liv.ac.uk ABSTRACT Work on argumentation-based dialogue has defined frameworks within which dialogues can be carried out, established protocols that govern dialogues, and studied different properties of dialogues.
This work has established the space in which agents are permitted to interact through dialogues.

Recently, there has been increasing interest in the mechanisms agents might use to choose how to act - the rhetorical manoeuvring that they use to navigate through the space defined by the rules of the dialogue.
Key in such considerations is the idea of relevance, since a usual requirement is that agents stay focussed on the subject of the dialogue and only make relevant remarks.
Here we study several notions of relevance, showing how they can be related to both the rules for carrying out dialogues and to rhetorical manoeuvring.
Categories and Subject Descriptors I.2.11 [Artificial Intelligence]: Distributed Artificial Intelligence: Coherence & co-ordination; languages & structures; multiagent systems.
General Terms Design, languages, theory. 1.
INTRODUCTION Finding ways for agents to reach agreements in multiagent systems is an area of active research.
One mechanism for achieving agreement is through the use of argumentation - where one agent tries to convince another agent of something during the course of some dialogue.

Early examples of argumentation-based approaches to multiagent agreement include the work of Dignum et al. [7], Kraus [14], Parsons and Jennings [16], Reed [23], Schroeder et al. [25] and Sycara [26].
The work of Walton and Krabbe [27], popularised in the multiagent systems community by Reed [23], has been particularly influential in the field of argumentation-based dialogue.
This work influenced the field in a number of ways, perhaps most deeply in framing multi-agent interactions as dialogue games in the tradition of Hamblin [13].

Viewing dialogues in this way, as in [2, 21], provides a powerful framework for analysing the formal properties of dialogues, and for identifying suitable protocols under which dialogues can be conducted [18, 20].
The dialogue game view overlaps with work on conversation policies (see, for example, [6, 10]), but differs in considering the entire dialogue rather than dialogue segments.
In this paper, we extend the work of [18] by considering the role of relevance - the relationship between utterances in a dialogue.

Relevance is a topic of increasing interest in argumentation-based dialogue because it relates to the scope that an agent has for applying strategic manoeuvering to obtain the outcomes that it requires [19, 22, 24].
Our work identifes the limits on such rhetorical manoeuvering, showing when it can and cannot have an effect. 2.
BACKGROUND We begin by introducing the formal system of argumentation that underpins our approach, as well as the corresponding terminology and notation, all taken from [2, 8, 17].
A dialogue is a sequence of messages passed between two or more members of a set of agents A.
An agent α maintains a knowledge base, Σα, containing formulas of a propositional language L and having no deductive closure.
Agent α also maintains the set of its past utterances, called the commitment store, CSα.
We refer to this as an agents public knowledge, since it contains information that is shared with other agents.
In contrast, the contents of Σα are private to α.
Note that in the description that follows, we assume that is the classical inference relation, that ≡ stands for logical equivalence, and we use Δ to denote all the information available to an agent.

Definition 2.1.

An argument A is a pair (S, p) where p is a formula of L and S a subset of Δ such that (i) S is consistent; (ii) S p; and (iii) S is minimal, so no proper subset of S satisfying both (1) and (2) exists.
S is called the support of A, written S = Support(A) and p is the conclusion of A, written p = Conclusion(A).
Thus we talk of p being supported by the argument (S, p).

In general, since Δ may be inconsistent, arguments in A(Δ), the set of all arguments which can be made from Δ, may conflict, and we make this idea precise with the notion of undercutting: Definition 2.2.
Let A1 and A2 be arguments in A(Δ).
A1 undercuts A2 iff ∃¬p ∈ Support(A2) such that p ≡ Conclusion(A1).
In other words, an argument is undercut if and only if there is another argument which has as its conclusion the negation of an element of the support for the first argument.
To capture the fact that some beliefs are more strongly held than others, we assume that any set of beliefs has a preference order over it.

We consider all information available to an agent, Δ, to be stratified into non-overlapping subsets Δ1, . . . , Δn such that beliefs in Δi are all equally preferred and are preferred over elements in Δj where i > j.

The preference level of a nonempty subset S ⊂ Δ, where different elements s ∈ S may belong to different layers Δi, is valued at the highest numbered layer which has a member in S and is referred to as level(S).
In other words, S is only as strong as its weakest member.
Note that the strength of a belief as used in this context is a separate concept from the notion of support discussed earlier.

If A1 is preferred to A2, we say that A1 is stronger than A2.

DIALOGUES Systems like those described in [2, 18], lay down sets of locutions that agents can make to put forward propositions and the arguments that support them, and protocols that define precisely which locutions can be made at which points in the dialogue.
We are not concerned with such a level of detail here.
Instead we are interested in the interplay between arguments that agents put forth.
As a result, we will consider only that agents are allowed to put forward arguments.

We do not discuss the detail of the mechanism that is used to put these arguments forward - we just assume that arguments of the form (S, p) are inserted into an agents commitment store where they are then visible to other agents.
We then have a typical definition of a dialogue: Definition 3.1.
A dialogue D is a sequence of moves: m1, m2, . . . , mn.
A given move mi is a pair α, Ai where Ai is an argument that α places into its commitment store CSα.
Moves in an argumentation-based dialogue typically attack moves that have been made previously.

While, in general, a dialogue can include moves that undercut several arguments, in the remainder of this paper, we will only consider dialogues that put forward moves that undercut at most one argument.
For now we place no additional constraints on the moves that make up a dialogue.
Later we will see how different restrictions on moves lead to different kinds of dialogue.

As indicated earlier, their choice is typically limited by a protocol.
If we write the sequence of n moves m1, m2, . . . , mn as mn, and denote the empty sequence as m0, then we can define a profocol in the following way: Definition 3.2.

A protocol P is a function on a sequence of moves mi in a dialogue D that, for all i ≥ 0, identifies a set of possible moves Mi+1 from which the mi+1th move may be drawn: P : mi → Mi+1 In other words, for our purposes here, at every point in a dialogue, a protocol determines a set of possible moves that agents may make as part of the dialogue.

If a dialogue D always picks its moves m from the set M identified by protocol P, then D is said to conform to P. Even if a dialogue conforms to a protocol, it is typically the case that the agent engaging in the dialogue has to make a choice of move - it has to choose which of the moves in M to make.
This excercise of choice is what we refer to as an agents use of rhetoric (in its oratorical sense of influencing the thought and conduct of an audience).
Some of our results will give a sense of how much scope an agent has to exercise rhetoric under different protocols.
As arguments are placed into commitment stores, and hence become public, agents can determine the relationships between them.
In general, after several moves in a dialogue, some arguments will undercut others.

Here we study three notions of relevance: Definition 4.1.
Consider a dialogue D, consisting of a sequence of moves mi, with a corresponding argument graph AG.

R2-relevance is the form of relevance defined by [3] in their study of strategic and tactical reasoning3 .
R1-relevance was suggested by the notion used in [15], and though it differs somewhat from that suggested there, we believe it captures the essence of its predecessor.

Note that we only define relevance for the second move of the dialogue onwards because the first move is taken to identify the subject of the dialogue, that is, the central question that the dialogue is intended to answer, and hence it must be relevant to the dialogue, no matter what it is.
In assuming this, we focus our attention on the same kind of dialogues as [18].
We can think of relevance as enforcing a form of parsimony on a dialogue - it prevents agents from making statements that do not bear on the current state of the dialogue.
This promotes efficiency, in the sense of limiting the number of moves in the dialogue, and, as in [15], prevents agents revealing information that they might better keep hidden.
Another form of parsimony is to insist that agents are not allowed to put forward arguments that will be undercut by arguments that have already been made during the dialogue.

COMPLETENESS The above discussion of the difference between dialogues carried out under single-path and bushy protocols brings us to the consideration of what [18] called predeterminism, but we now prefer to describe using the term completeness.

The idea of predeterminism, as described in [18], captures the notion that, under some circumstances, the result of a dialogue can be established without actually having the dialogue - the agents have sufficiently little room for rhetorical manoeuver that were one able to see the contents of all the Σi of all the αi ∈ A, one would be able to identify the outcome of any dialogue on a given subject4 .
We develop this idea by considering how the argument graphs constructed by dialogues under different protocols compare to benchmark complete dialogues.
We start by developing ideas of what complete might mean.
One reasonable definition is that: Definition 5.1.

A basic dialogue D between the set of agents A with a corresponding argumentation graph AG is topic-complete if no agent can construct an argument A that undercuts any argument A represented by a
node
in AG.

The argumentation graph constructed by a topic-complete dialogue is called a topic-complete argumentation graph and is denoted AG(D)T . 4 Assuming that the Σi do not change during the dialogue, which is the usual assumption in this kind of dialogue.
A dialogue is topic-complete when no agent can add anything that is directly connected to the subject of the dialogue.
Some protocols will prevent agents from making moves even though the dialogue is not topic-complete.
To distinguish such cases we have: Definition 5.2.

A basic dialogue D between the set of agents A with a corresponding argumentation graph AG is protocol-complete under a protocol P if no agent can make a move that adds a
node
to the argumentation graph that is permitted by P. The argumentation graph constructed by a protocol-complete dialogue is called a protocol-complete argumentation graph and is denoted AG(D)P .
Clearly: Proposition 5.1.
Any dialogue D under a basic protocol P is protocol-complete if it is topic-complete.
The converse does not hold in general.
Proof.
If D is topic-complete, no agent can make a move that will extend the argumentation graph.
This means that no agent can make a move that is permitted by a basic protocol, and so D is also protocol complete.

The converse does not hold since some basic dialogues (under a protocol that only permits R3-relevant moves, for example) will not permit certain moves (like the addition of a
node
that connects to the root of the argumentation graph after more than two moves) that would be allowed in a topiccomplete dialogue.
Corollary 5.1.
For a basic dialogue D, AG(D)P is a sub-graph of AG(D)T .
Obviously, from the definition of a sub-graph, the converse of Corollary 5.1 does not hold in general.

The important distinction between topic- and protocolcompleteness is that the former is determined purely by the state of the dialogue - as captured by the argumentation graph - and is thus independent of the protocol, while the latter is determined entirely by the protocol.
Any time that a dialogue ends in a state of protocol-completeness rather than topic completeness, it is ending when agents still have things to say but cant because the protocol wont allow them to.

With these definitions of completeness, our task is to relate topic-completeness - the property that ensures that agents can say everything that they have to say in a dialogue that is, in some sense, important - to the notions of relevance we have developed - which determine what agents are allowed to say.
When we need very specific conditions to make protocol-complete dialogues topic-complete, it means that agents have lots of room for rhetorical maneouver when those conditions are not in force.
That is there are many ways they can bring dialogues to a close before everything that can be said has been said.
Where few conditions are required, or conditions are absent, then dialogues between agents with the same knowledge will always play out the same way, and rhetoric has no place.
We have: Proposition 5.2.

A protocol-complete basic dialogue D under a protocol which only allows R3-relevant moves will be topic-complete only when AG(D)T has a single branch in which the nodes are labelled in increasing order from the root.

u on the path that represents an argument whose status is fixed somehow, and that must mean that there is another chain of undercut relations, another branch of the tree, that is incident at u.
Since this second branch denotes another chain of arguments, and these affect the status of the argument denoted by u, they must also affect the status of A.
Any of these are the A in the condition.

So an R2-relevant move m is not R1-relevant if either its effect is blocked because an argument upstream is not strong enough, or because there is another line of argument that is currently determining the status of the argument at the root.
This, in turn, means that if the effect is not due to defending against, then there is an alternative move that is R1-relevant - a move that undercuts A in the second condition above5 .
We can now show 5 Though whether the agent in question can make such a move is another question.
Proposition 5.4.
A protocol-complete basic dialogue D will always be topic-complete under a protocol which only includes R2-relevant moves and allows every R2-relevant move to be made.

The restriction on R2-relevant rules is exactly that for topiccompleteness, so a dialogue that has only R2-relevant moves will continue until every argument that any agent can make has been put forward.
Given this, and what we revealed about R1-relevance in Proposition 5.3, we can see that: Proposition 5.5.

A protocol-complete basic dialogue D under a protocol which only includes R1-relevant moves will be topic-complete if AG(D)T : 1. includes no path with adjacent nodes v, denoting A, and v , denoting A , such that A undercuts A and A is stronger that A; and 2. is such that the nodes in every branch have consecutive indices and no
node

Proof.
The first condition rules out the first condition in Proposition 5.3, and the second deals with the situation that leads to the second condition in Proposition 5.3.

The second condition ensures that each branch is constructed in full before any new branch is added, and when a new branch is added, the argument that is undercut as part of the addition will be acceptable, and so the addition will change the status of the argument denoted by that
node
, and hence the root.
With these conditions, every move required to construct AG(D)T will be permitted and so the dialogue will be topic-complete when every move has been completed.
The second part of this result only identifies one possible way to ensure that the second condition in Proposition 5.3 is met, so the converse of this result does not hold.
However, what we have is sufficient to answer the question about predetermination that we started with.
For dialogues to be predetermined, every move that is R2-relevant must be made.
In such cases every dialogue is topic complete.
If we do not require that all R2-relevant moves are made, then there is some room for rhetoric - the way in which alternative lines of argument are presented becomes an issue.
If moves are forced to be R3-relevant, then there is considerable room for rhetorical play. 6.

SUMMARY This paper has studied the different ideas of relevance in argumentation-based dialogue, identifying the relationship between these ideas, and showing how they can impact the extent to which the way that agents choose moves in a dialogue - what some authors have called the strategy and tactics of a dialogue.

This extends existing work on relvance, such as [3, 15] by showing how different notions of relevance can have an effect on the outcome of a dialogue, in particular when they render the outcome predetermined.
This connection extends the work of [18] which considered dialogue outcome, but stopped short of identifying the conditions under which it is predetermined.
There are two ways we are currently trying to extend this work, both of which will generalise the results and extend its applicability.
First, we want to relax the restrictions that 1012 The Sixth Intl.

Joint Conf. on Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems (AAMAS 07) we have imposed, the exclusion of moves that attack several arguments (without which the argument graph can be mulitply-connected) and the exclusion of pre-empted moves, without which the argument graph can have cycles.

Second, we want to extend the ideas of relevance to cope with moves that do not only add undercutting arguments, but also supporting arguments, thus taking account of bipolar argumentation frameworks [5].
